Diagnostics

Opioids can be qualitatively detected using immunoassays. However, if quantitative measurements are indicated, chromatography is necessary. Because of such factors as metabolism and fluid intake, there is no clear relationship between the amount of opioid excreted in urine and the amount ingested.

Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that reverses the toxic manifestations opioid intoxication. If signs and symptoms resolve with therapeutic doses of naloxone, then the diagnosis of opioid intoxication is highly likely.

  • Administer 0.2 mg of naloxone intravenously.
  • If no adverse reactions occur after 30 seconds, administer a second dose at 0.6 mg IV.
  • Observe for 30 minutes for signs of opioid withdrawal.
  • When in doubt, administer an additional dose at 1.6 mg IV.
